sentences: From 1988 to 2000, Kitagawa was the subject of a number of claims that he had taken advantage of his position to engage in improper sexual relationships with boys under contract to his talent agency.
Kitagawa denied these claims, and in 2002 was awarded an 8.8 million yen judgment against the magazine that had published such allegations.
Born in 1931 in Los Angeles, California, United States, Kitagawa returned with his family to Japan in 1933.
Born in 1931 in Los Angeles, California, United States, Kitagawa returned with his family to Japan in 1933.
His older sister is Mary Yasuko Fujishima, while his father Taido was a Buddhist priest and was the third head bishop of the Koyasan Buddhist Temple in Little Tokyo from 1924 to 1933.
Kitagawa went to America about 1949, and he taught English to orphans from the Korean War for the United States Army.
In 1968, Kitagawa achieved wider success with a four-member boy band known as Four Leaves.
The song and dance group met with success, as reflected by seven consecutive appearances on the annual invitation-only Kōhaku Uta Gassen, beginning in 1970.
Four Leaves performed together for ten years before disbanding in 1978.
Later, in 2002, Kitagawa oversaw the band's reunion.
During 1997, performers belonging to the talent agency appeared in more than 40 television programs and another 40 commercials.

Rumors concerning Kitagawa and possible sexual harassment of the youth in his employ had surrounded the agency since 1988, when Koji Kita (北公次, Kita Kōji), a former member of Four Leaves, published a series of diaries under the title Hikaru Genji e (光Genjiへ, Dear Hikaru Genji).
section: == Sexual harassment claims and libel suit ==

sentences: Similar allegations were made in a book published in 1996 by Junya Hiramoto, a former member of another of Kitagawa's bands.
section: == Sexual harassment claims and libel suit ==

sentences: Later, in 1999, the weekly magazine Shukan Bunshun printed a ten-part series that detailed numerous allegations of sexual improprieties.
section: == Sexual harassment claims and libel suit ==

sentences: The controversy resulted in Yoshihide Sakaue, a member of the Parliament, holding a hearing on the matter in April, 2000.
section: == Sexual harassment claims and libel suit ==

sentences: After protracted litigation, in 2002 the Tokyo District Court awarded Kitagawa an 8.8 million yen judgment against Shukan Bunshun, finding that the articles defamed him.
section: == Sexual harassment claims and libel suit ==

sentences: In a partial reversal of the district court, the Tokyo High Court in 2003 ruled that the Shukan Bunshun series did in fact defame Kitagawa; however, it ruled that the defamatory content of the articles was limited to the allegations that Kitagawa had provided minors with alcohol and tobacco products.
section: == Sexual harassment claims and libel suit ==

sentences: Kitagawa appealed this decision to the Supreme Court, but in 2004 it rejected his appeal.
section: == Sexual harassment claims and libel suit ==

sentences: On July 9, 2019, Kitagawa died at a hospital in Tokyo after suffering a subarachnoid hemorrhage stroke on June 18, at the age of 87.
A memorial concert was held on September 4, 2019 at the Tokyo Dome, with 154 Johnny's artists and other celebrities including Akiko Wada and Dewi Sukarno in attendance.
A 2004 appeal to the Supreme Court by Kitagawa was rejected.
In the early 1950s, he returned to Japan to work at the United States Embassy.

sentences: John Hiromu Kitagawa (喜多川 擴, Kitagawa Hiromu, October 23, 1931 – July 9, 2019), known professionally as Johnny Kitagawa (ジャニー喜多川, Janī Kitagawa), was a Japanese-American businessman and talent manager.
Regarded as one of the most powerful figures in the Japanese entertainment industry, he held a virtual monopoly on the creation of boy bands in Japan for more than 40 years.
Four Leaves performed together for ten years before disbanding in 1978.
Kitagawa holds an annual summer festival known as "Johnny's Summary".
Shonentai, for example, did not release a single until it had been together for more than seven years.
"I'm not very interested in records," Kitagawa said in a 1996 interview.
On July 9, 2019, Kitagawa died at a hospital in Tokyo after suffering a subarachnoid hemorrhage stroke on June 18, at the age of 87.
